titleStmt.title: Dispatch from William Walker to William H. Seward, December 20, 1861

bibl.title: Dispatch from William Walker to William H. Seward, December 20, 1861
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

div1.note: After making the copies please vet Mr. Gilbert to appear it the certificate
div1.opener:
Gaboon W. Africa Dec. 20 1861
Hon.W.H.Seward
Washington
Sir
div1.p: Your communication of July 3rd, and Circular of August 28th with the form of the Oath of Allegiance have been received. The duties of the Agency in Gaboon have not been onerous. In consequence of the Presidents Proclamation of July, I think, relating to Citizens of the United States returning to the States, I gave a certificate of citizenship to Miss Jane A. VanAllen, who sailed from this port Nov. 1st in its Brig 'Ocean Eagle', Phillip D. Yates Minister, bound to New York. As this is a free port, & neither my duties as a Missionary permitting or the interest of humanity requiring, I did not perform any official duties toward the vessel. I also am in doubt whether your letter of July 3rd authroizing any such official acts.

But it is now my painful duty to inform you of the death of Capt. R.E.Lawlin of New York. Agent for James Bishop H.O. of No. 3. Beaver I Street New York. Captain Lawlin was a trader of thirty years standing on this Coast. He died at Camma, about 150. miles South of the Gaboon. His principal business was at that place. He had no responsible person about him. I have send the best man I could find, to go & take charge of the property until I can find the means of bringing it to this place. I have written to the U.S. Sloop Saratoga, & the French Commodere, Baron Didelad has offered any assistance in his power. But I shall not be able to give you particular information before the departure of this month's mail. I have no means of estimating the amount of property left in Camma. It is in the midst of a barbarous people.

21st. I have just returned from paying a visit to the Commodore. He told me at once that he had read a communication (the enclosed) which I had the honor to address to him on the 18th Inst., at his request for a written statement of the Case of Capt. Lawlin. He proposed at once to send a steamer to protect the property in case the natives made any resistance to its removal. End

In regard to the Oath of Allegiance he said there was no one here authorized to administer the oath, but he would direct the Commandant on shore to writing my signature to it this I will attend to at my earliest convience, [The Commodore asured me that the simple request as an American citizen, for assistance to secure the property of an American citizen was all he required. I have engaged an English Barque to go & bring the goods to this place. I have written very fully to Messrs James Bishop H.O, & have requested
3
them to despatch an Agent immediately to take charge of this business I shall try & keep within the law in my business transactions & must beg your indulgence for any informalities in my communications.

I would simply add that after considerable inquiry, I suppose the amount of African produce & goods in the factory at Camma must be between $10,000 & $15,000 ten thousand & fifteen thousand dollars. My associate in Missionary labor, Rev. J. M. Preston, will go to Camma in the vessel to attend to the shipping of the goods & settling up Capt. Lawlins business there. The is a perfectly reliable man. It seems to be impossible for me to go.

closer.salute: I am Sir, Your obedient Servant
